“**一度も登らぬ馬鹿、二度登る馬鹿**”

> "He who climbs Mt. Fuji is a wise man; he who climbs twice is a fool.” [^1]

[^1]: Fujisan (富士山) or Mount Fuji, is the highest mountain peak in Japan at 3,776 meters (12,389 feet).

I disagree with above statement.

Mountains, towers, buildings and structures changes as we repeat the visit. Or is that we change as we return to the place that we seemingly know well.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Venues that I thought were large, upon a return visit, they seem manageable.

> No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it's not the same river and he's not the same man.

Heraclitus

Read more at https://www.brainyquote.com/authors/heraclitus-quotes

What appears to be insurmountable or unfathomable becomes more accessable and understandable.

Wedding venues seem to shrink as one visits. Church buildings take on the local flavor

Man erects edifices to inspire. Without people it is a structure. With people it becomes a living edifice

Do we transform the environment or are we transformed by it.

> “We shape our buildings; thereafter they shape us,”

said Sir Winston Churchill in his speech to the meeting in the House of Lords, October 28, 1943, requesting that the House of Commons bombed out in May 1941 be rebuilt exactly as before.

Although we did not shape nature, the nature still shape us.

Drawn to places and food that reflect nature.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

American-born British petroleum industrialist, Jean Paul Getty, created a modern day. Acropolis.

A high city, where people can gather to worship the new god.
